channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2023100344
item.description:
Report E-2023100344

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-02
  • City: MINNEAPOLIS
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 2, 2023, four (4) 55-gallon drums of UN3093 arrived without caps and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EX Environmental (EXE) to remediate the impacted site. Three of the lids were re-secured and the facility had to provide a fourth. The drums were sent back with the driver. EXE personnel deployed absorbents and absorbent pads to the ferric nitrate solution-impacted trailer interior. All spent absorbent pads and absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport to the terminal.

item.title: Report E-2023100330
item.description:
Report E-2023100330

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-10
  • City: GLENPOOL
  • State: OK
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LTU experienced a UN1791 Extract-2 release from (2) 55-gallon poly drums. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-cups of product released to the drum lids of each drum due to loose bung caps. The released product was cleaned off the drums with absorbent rags and the caps were re-secured for shipment on. All impacted absorbent pads and PPE were containerized into a 45-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100326
item.description:
Report E-2023100326

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-10
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: KS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XKC experienced a UN3266 Enrich No. 299 release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment and cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 3-ounces of product released to the drum lid due to the drum being dropped, causing a puncture. The damaged drum was placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. All impacted rags used to clean the release were placed into a 5-gallon poly pail. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: OLEAN
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XON experienced a UN2693 Sodium Bisulfite Solution 40% release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a gouge in the top of the tote. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into (2) 275-gallon poly totes. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents into (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The tote was wiped down and the cap was replaced with a new vented bung. The damaged cap, impacted rags, and PPE were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The pail and material released were correctly containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The 35-gallon empty contaminated metal drum was placed into a separate 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • State: AZ

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UPH experienced a NA1760 Platinum Plus Wheel Cleaner release from a 5-gallon poly pail. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment and cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released to a 4’ x 4’ area of the trailer floor due to the pail being crushed by improper loading. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. The damaged jug and all cleanup debris was then collected into a 15-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100221
item.description:
Report E-2023100221

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LSX experienced a UN3082 Permafil 74041 release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of product released to a 20’ x 15’ area of the dock floor due to a puncture. The product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area and then collected into a 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized into a 95-gallon poly overpack. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LDA experienced a UN1866 Vinyl Ester Resin release from (2) 250-gallon poly totes. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment and cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 cup of product released to the tote body only of each tote. The caps were replaced, and a slosh test conducted to ensure there would be no further release. The totes were wiped down for shipment on. All impacted rags, the damaged caps, and PPE were containerized into a 5-gallon poly pail. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XLA experienced a UN3265 Turpinal SL release from a 10-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment and cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 5’ x 7’ area of the dock floor due to a puncture. Absorbents and sodium bicarb were deployed and worked into the impacted area to clean and neutralize the release. The damaged pail and cleanup debris were then containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release was caused by a loose bung cap and contained to the trailer floor and a small area of asphalt below the trailer. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 20-gallons of product released to a 23' x 5' area of the trailer floor and a 50’ x 2’ area of the gravel lot below due to a puncture caused by a broken pallet. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Floor dry and a citric acid solution were then deployed and utilized to clean the impacted areas. The impacted gravel was shoveled up and the area pH came back at a 7 once all contaminants were removed. All impacted gravel and absorbents were containerized into (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was transported to the XPO terminal located in Tomah, WI and staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100305
item.description:
Report E-2023100305

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-28
  • City: SCHENECTADY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/28/2023 a Veolia employee unloading drums from a truck into another trailer at the Veolia, Schenectady, NY 10 day intransit facility when the employee noticed that a 14 gallon fiber drum was stained and damp. The 14 gallon drum contained a 2.5 gallon glass bottle of Formic Acid With Not Less Than 5% But Less Than 10% Acid By Mass corrosive liquids. The outer container was opened and the inner container was inspected and was found to be broken and released its contents. No liquid was released from the outer packaging drum. The 14 gallon drum containing the broken glass bottle was overpacked into an 30 gallon 1H2 drum and transportation to the ultimate disposal facility was continued. The drum did not leak any amount of the corrosive liquid solution out of the outer container.

item.title: Report E-2023100304
item.description:
Report E-2023100304

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-21
  • City: ABBOTSFORD
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While parked at a Kwik Trip truck stop, the Veolia driver noticed liquid dripping out of the trailer. Upon investigation, he found a leaking drum with a puncture near the bottom of the container. An overpack was placed underneath the leak to contain as much of the spill as possible until the remediation crew arrived. Approximately 20 gallons of liquid leaked out of the drum. Kwik Trip contacted and emergency response company to assist with clean-up.

item.title: Report E-2023100303
item.description:
Report E-2023100303

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-12
  • City: AZUSA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A Veolia driver initially picked up the drum in question on 9/5/2023 from the offeror and the trailer was used to pick up other materials on 9/12/23. The driver noticed that there was some liquid on the front of the trailer along with oily stains on the back of the trailer. Veolia personnel started to remove the drums from the trailer and identified the leaking drum which was located at the nose of the trailer. The leaking drum was a 55 gal metal drum with a pin hole leak that appeared to occur from potentially rubbing/impact against another drum during transportation which was a weak spot due to corrosion. The driver made multiple stops that day and he has stated that he did not notice any staining on the back-end of the trailer when he loaded addition drums at each stop. Also he did not notice any oily material near or around the front of the trailer during those stops. We are unsure of the duration of the spill but based on the quantity still left in the drum, roughly 5 gallons had leaked out. The drum was placed into a salvage drum and the spill clean up was completed by the Veolia in-house crew. Most of the material was contained inside the trailer with minimal amounts outside of the trailer. There was no evidence of a any spill on the ground itself.

  • City: EVANSTON

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Loaf'N Jug
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 09, 2023, at 1945 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Loaf'N Jug's personnel in Evanston, Wyoming regarding the release of approximately (50) gallons of Diesel Fuel (UN1202 3, III) from (1) tank truck. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed that the release was contained to asphalt and concrete. The local fire department arrived prior to the contractors and placed absorbents. The first round of absorbents were cleaned UP and containerized, then the contractors added more to confirm that all the release was absorbed and collected. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (1) 55-gallon metal drum which was staged onsite in preparation for proper disposal.

  • Description: On September 27, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon jug of UN3265 was punctured by a nail and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. . Crews deployed neutralizing granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and cleanup debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The damaged 5-gallon jug of corrosive liquid was placed inside one (1) 30-gallon poly drum for disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2023100224

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-12T15:12:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-26
  • City: DAVENPORT
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 26, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2735 was punctured and released approximately fifty (50) gallons of product to the trailer floor and concrete parking lot. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES placed the damaged drum into one (1) 85-gallon overpack for transport and disposal. ES deployed a neutralizing agent and absorbents to the trailer floor and concrete parking lot. The crew utilized absorbent pads to wipe underneath the trailer. ES collected the spent absorbents into five (5) drums for transport and disposal. On September 28, 2023, ES returned to the site. ES utilized a combination of a neutralizer, absorbent wipes, and hand tools to remove the residue buildup generated from the original cleanup. The crew placed the spent neutralizer and absorbents into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal. ES staged the drum onsite to be processed via R+L's normal waste stream.

item.title: Report E-2023100223
item.description:
Report E-2023100223

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-12T15:12:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-27
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 27, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3098 was dropped by a forklift and released approximately five (5) gallons to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel deployed poly sheeting, pH neutralizers, soda ash, granular absorbents, and pad absorbents to theUN3098-impacted areas and collected them with hand tools. TLE personnel cut out the impacted wood debris from the trailer and after collection of waste and debris flushed the trailer. All spent absorbents and debris were collected into two (2) lined 35-gallon poly drums, one with the impacted, diluted pail inside and the other with miscellaneous waste and debris, along with a lined 55-gallon poly drum containing mixed waste and cleanup debris.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: ERTS was contacted by Tim Pfeffer (Roadrunner Transportation Systems) regarding an approx. 1 gallon release of UN1993 - "D-Limonene Standard" on the Bay dock due to a forklift puncture. The caller has requested a contractor out for cleanup and containment. ERTS dispatched Hepaco Environmental personnel. HEPACO confirmed product released as UN1993 - "D-Limonene Standard. Spill is no longer visible as it has evaporated. The drum was turned upside down by onsite staff as an effort to stop the active leak. Hepaco will place the drum in (1) 65-Gal DM overpack. The overpack drum was staged on site pending disposal confirmation.

  • Description: Enviroserve was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 1ft-by-1ft area of the trailer floor and terminal floor and estimated that one (1) gallon of material was released due to damaged valve assembly causing the release of material. Enviroserve personnel transferred the remaining material in the damaged 330-gallon metal tote to eight 55-gallon metal drums. Enviroserve personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas and collected the spent material and placed into one of the 55-gallon metal drums. The generated waste was staged onsite in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Response Management Services (RMS) to remediate the impacted site.   • Description: On September 22, 2023, two (2) 5-gallon pails of UN3265 were crushed in transit and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from SET Environmental (SET) to remediate the impacted site. The damaged jugs were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area and utilized absorbent wipes to remove residual product from the remaining two (2) undamaged jugs. All UN3265-impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal.

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-11T15:10:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-27
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: During receiving/off-loading at Veolia's facility in Phoenix, AZ Veolia employees observed liquid coming from the bottom a 30 gallon fiber drum that was stacked on top of 55 gallon poly drums. Vials containing liquid COD reagent were packed into a fiber drum with no added absorbent or cushioning material. A 6 mil poly bag containing the vials was used as a liner/inner packaging, but apparently it was not sufficient to stop a release of liquid. The containers were removed from the receiving area and placed into the processing area within facility on a spill containment pallet. Notifications were made to the shipping location with instructions to ship this type of material in poly drums in the future to avoid spillage.

  • Description: TILX 160815 was reported to be leaking from the Bottom Outlet Valve (BOV). An estimated 2 ounces of product leaked from the BOV nozzle threads and cap. The cap was less then tool tight, adding Teflon tape to the threads and tightening the cap stopped the release. The BOV was in the closed position. Product in the nozzle was residue from off-loading operations. The shipper's facility is next the location of release. The shipper will route the car back to their facility and preform an additional inspection.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Description: ERS of OK was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 25ft-by-8ft area of the trailer floor, a 15ft-by-1ft area of concrete parking lot and a 1ft-by-1ft area of soil. ERS of OK personnel estimated that fifteen (15) gallons of material was released due to improper loading of the freight damaging eight (8) 5-gallon plastic pails. ERS of OK personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted areas and used a granular absorbent to collect the spent material. The recovered material and impacted freight were placed into two (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The eight (8) damaged 5-gallon poly pails were containerized into two (55-gallon) poly drums. Additional impacted freight was placed into two (2) DOT contractor bags. The generated waste was transported offsite by ERS of OK personnel for disposal. The disposal of the waste will be coordinated by the ESTES DGRM team.

item.title: Report I-2023090145
item.description:
Report I-2023090145

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-11T15:10:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-31
  • City: La Habra
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: UPS DRIVER PICKED UP PACKAGE FROM CUSTOMER LOCATION, AS DRIVER WAS COMING DOWN EAST PARKWOOD AVE TO MAKE HIS NEXT DELIVERY, HE BEGAN TO SMELL SOMETHING BURNING SO HE PULLED OVER. DRIVER OPENED THE BULKHEAD DOOR AND SAW BACK OF HIS CR FULL SMOKE SO HE JUMPED OUT. LEFT THE BULKHEAD DOOR OPEN AND CALLED THE SUPERVISOR TO NOTIFY HIM OF THE INCIDENT. SUPERVISOR FOLLOWED CHAIN OF COMMAND. MANAGER CALLED 911. OUTSIDE RESPONDER WAS CONTACTED. 1500 THE FIRE DEPARTMENT ARRIVED SHORTLY AFTER AND REMOVE SMOKING PACKAGE FROM PACKAGE CAR. AT THIS TIME, THEY BEGAN TO DO EMERGENCY MITIGATION BY SPRAYING WATER ONTO THE PACKAGE TO BRING DOWN THE TEMPERATURE AROUND 15:30, AT 17:50 THE OUTSIDE RESPONDER "PATRIOT ENVIRONMENTAL" ARRIVED ON THE SCENE AND THE FIRE DEPARTMENT STOP PUTTING WATER ON THE PACKAGE. THEY PUT SAND ON THE CONTENTS OF THE PACKAGE AND BEGAN BREAKING THE CONTENTS TO REMOVE THE BATTERIES.FROM THIS POINT THEY MONITORED THE TEMPERATURES OF THE PACKAGE TO ENSURE THEY WERE DROPPING. TEMPERATURE WAS STILL UNSTABLE FOR THE NEXT COUPLE OF HOURS. AROUND 20:00 THE TEMPERATURE OF THE PACKAGE WAS STABLE ENOUGH AND THEY WERE GOING TO START THE PROCESS OF CLEANING UP AND PROCESSING THE CONTENTS OF THE SPILL .OUTSIDE RESPONDER TOOK ALL CONTENTS.

  • City: Edina

  • Carrier/Reporter: UNIVAR SOLUTIONS USA INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver arrived at customer location to fill a Dimethylformamide(DMF) tank. He verified the tank, quantity, and connection prior to starting to pump. After several moments after beginning transfer, customer employee notified driver that nothing was transferring. Driver inspected the connections and proceeded to check on the internal valve, which he closed and opened again. After doing so a cap on the rear of the trailer popped off and product started coming out of the open pipe. Driver shutdown the pump and approximately 90 gallons of DMF spilled into the customer's containment. The cause of the release was the result of a faulty outlet cap. During the investigation it was determined that there was no isolation valve installed behind the cap.

  • Description: A mother had her infant baby with her on American Airlines Flight 1680 when the baby soiled its diaper creating a strong odor in the cabin. The mother got up to change the baby's diaper when another woman sitting nearby removed a canister of pepper spray from her purse and sprayed it on the mother and her baby inadvertently also striking two Flight Attendants with pepper spray nearby. The flight was enroute from Miami, FL to New York, La Guardia when this occurred. The Captain diverted the flight to Jacksonville, FL where airport police met the flight. American Airlines Corporate Security spoke to the woman who said she thought she was spraying the mother and infant with air freshener and mistakenly grabbed the wrong dispenser causing the incident. It is unknown how the customer got through TSA security without the pepper spray being detected.

  • Description: 1. A customer stopped FA during boarding and said her vape was hot and asked him to throw it away 2. Customer mentioned the device may have been damaged while in her bag 3. FA noticed light smoke(possibly vape?) coming from the device 4. FA asked customer to wait as throwing it away may not be safe 5. Customer had a paper towel(possibly napkin) and wrapped the vape inside 6. Customer essentially put it in the FAs hands to dispose of it 7. FA immediately took it to the forward galley and submerged it in a cup of water to contain/cool 8. FA noted the device did not feel hot when carrying it to the front 9. CSR appeared moments later and FA notified CSR 10. FA asked CSR what to do with the device 11. CSR then took the cup of water, with the vape submerged inside, offthe aircraft 12. Later, the same CSR advised FA that she had given it over to her supervisor 13. FA is unsure of CSR name or CSR supervisor name 14. FA is unsure of customer ID or seat number as it occurred during boarding with many customers standing in the aisle 15. FA confirmed the device was a vape, but did not unwrap from towel or pull out of water to inspect

  • Description: On 7/25/2023, personnel at CSX Russel, KY yard, reported UTLX671478, a loaded tank car of Xylenols, was observed leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and SASOL Chemicals was notified via CHEMTREC (report #2023-07-25-00337). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found (1) of (8) manway cover bolts less than tool tight. The manway bolts were tightened tool tight and the released Xylenols was cleaned from the top of the car. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to SASOL Chemicals representative Randy Shilling (832-783-6428, Randy.Shilling@us.sasol.com). Delay in report submission due to online portal would not accept.

  • Description: Denatured ethanol leaking from defective pressure relief device on tank car. Unknown amount (1 lbs) to car sides. Car crew member reported some spilling from top of car last night but TM couldn't find any evidence of spill during day. No waterways, no injuries. USE doing tank car inspection found defective PRD. PRD was found stuck in to the open position, responders were able to reset the valve. Shipper was notified of defective PRD. A transload is schedule so the empty car can move to destination for repair/inspection. All spill ethanol evaporated from the tank car body, no impacts to soil.

item.title: Report I-2023090114
item.description:
Report I-2023090114

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-12T00:30:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-10
  • City: Caprock
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: COASTAL TRANSPORT CO., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The cargo tank motor vehicle(CTMV) was traveling on highway 380 near mile marker 200. The CTMV experienced a tire blow out on axle four, passenger side tire. The driver was unable to stop safely as the one lane each direction roadway contained no improved or paved shoulder for emergency stops. The driver was forced to travel approximately 1.5 miles at slow speed before the driver could slowly stop at a roadside pull out. The skidding tire overheated and Ignited with flames. After stopping, the driver used the on board fire extinguisher In attempt to extingulsh the fire. The flames quickly grew and ignited the product hoses slowed on the equipment tray that is mounted on the passenger side, below the cargo compartments. The fire/heat quickly melted through the aluminum shell of the cargo compartments. As the compartment shells melted through, the flammable liquid ignited. The fire consumed the cargo tank motor vehicle(truck tractor/semi-trailer) and product. The Caprock volunteer fire department contained the blaze and allowed the product to be consumed by the fire. Approximately 150 gallons of diesel fuel remained in the bottom of the compartment shell after the fire was extinguished. This product was picked up and disposed of by the local HM response vendor that was called to the scene. The vehicle wreckage was loaded onto a flatbed semi-trailer and carried away for disposal. The HM response vendor scraped and cleaned the pavement area.
